error.signature: System.PlatformNotSupportedException: Operation is not supported on this platform.

verdict.summary: PlatformNotSupportedException is thrown when calling APIs that are not available on the current OS or runtime. Common when using Windows-specific APIs (Registry, Windows Forms, WMI) on Linux containers, or when using APIs trimmed by the .NET linker. Fix by using cross-platform alternatives or conditional compilation.

dead_ends.action: Installing Windows compatibility packages on Linux to get Windows-only APIs
dead_ends.why_fails: The Microsoft.Windows.Compatibility pack provides some APIs on Linux but many still throw PlatformNotSupportedException at runtime because they depend on Windows OS services (Registry, WMI, COM) that simply do not exist on Linux

dead_ends.action: Using reflection to bypass platform checks and call internal methods
dead_ends.why_fails: Platform checks exist because the underlying OS capability is absent; bypassing the check just moves the failure to a lower level with a more cryptic error (DllNotFoundException, EntryPointNotFoundException) or causes undefined behavior

workarounds.how: Replace Windows-specific APIs with cross-platform alternatives: use System.IO instead of Registry for config storage, use System.Diagnostics.Process instead of WMI for process management, use SkiaSharp instead of System.Drawing for image processing. Check the .NET Platform Compatibility Analyzer (CA1416) warnings

workarounds.action: Use conditional compilation or runtime platform checks
workarounds.how: Use OperatingSystem.IsWindows()/IsLinux() for runtime checks: if (OperatingSystem.IsWindows()) { /* Windows-only code */ } else { /* cross-platform fallback */ }. For compile-time: #if WINDOWS ... #else ... #endif with <DefineConstants>WINDOWS</DefineConstants> in .csproj. Enable the platform compatibility analyzer by adding <EnableNETAnalyzers>true</EnableNETAnalyzers>

leads_to.condition: when cross-platform alternative requires a native library not installed on the target OS
when platform-specific code fails in a Docker Linux container

preceded_by.condition: when a Windows-developed application is deployed to a Linux Docker container
when building on a different platform than the target reveals platform-specific dependencies

frequently_confused_with.distinction: PlatformNotSupportedException means the API exists but is not implemented for this platform; FileNotFoundException for assemblies means the required DLL is completely missing from the deployment
